Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Taiwan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Joseph Hollmann of Northeastern University to conduct a research project in Biology during the summer of 2013 at National Taiwan University in Taipei. The project title is "Analysis and Modeling of Ultrasound-Modulated Light in Tissue to Reduce the Effects of Scattering." The host scientist is Professor Snow Tseng.

Optical interrogation of tissue uses non-ionizing radiation and has high biological specificity. However, its application in biomedical imaging is limited because, in most tissues, scattering masks physiologically important information such as optical absorption. Recent work has shown phase conjugation of a scattered probe beam can be utilized to reduce scattering and allow for focusing deep within tissue. We can dynamically determine this focal point by modulating an optical wave with an ultrasound beam to create a reference point, or "guidestar," and achieve ultrasound resolution imaging to depths of multiple millimeters. This project analyzes the coherent properties of an optical signal propagating in a scattering medium to determine its effects on the formation of the ultrasound-modulated guidestar.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, the Fellow will extend the benefits of this experience to others in several ways. First, the results will be presented to Prof. Tseng's research group at the conclusion of the program. Second, after traveling back to the United States, the research as well as the experience in Taiwan as a Fellow will be presented to the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering at Northeastern University. During the fall, the Fellow will travel to Brownsville, Texas, a community with a large minority population, and offer a series of discussions to local high school students about engineering, research and the experience in Taiwan. The Fellow will mentor students in programs designed to enhance representation of under-served populations, such as the Young Scholars and Research Experience for Undergrads programs. Finally, the Fellow will continue to collaborate with Prof. Tseng's group to ensure the results of the summer?s work are disseminated by publishing papers and giving presentations at conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to study coherent optical field propagation through a highly scattering medium. In earlier research, I noted the formation of localized channels of optical energy within a scattering medium, which is surprising because this is not predicted by the Radiative Transport Equation (RTE). Even though the RTE is fundamentally incoherent, its numerical solutions are utilized as ``gold standards" for optical propagation in a diffusive medium. Furthermore, the optical channels have a width of approximately one optical wavelength, yet they remain coherent over long distances. This appears to violate diffraction theory, which predicts the channels should quickly diverge. However, even more surprising, is that the channels of energy retain coherence for lengths greater than one transport mean--free path in the medium, which defies diffusion theory as well.

To understand why light behaves in this manner, I developed a method for following the coherent optical propagation through the scattering medium. I was able to apply this technique to simulation results of an optical field propagating through a scattering medium. While studying this problem, I was able to verify my FDTD simulation results with Professor Snow Tseng's psuedo--spectral time domain results. Both simulations are discretized solutions to Maxwell's equations for electromagnetic wave propagation but each method solves the equations in a different manner These unpublished results illustrate the validity of both solutions in a scattering medium.

This research has resulted in the submission of two abstracts to Photonics West, which is the major conference in optics. Both abstracts were accepted and I will be presenting the following two papers at the conference this February: "A model for ultrasound modulated light in a turbid medium" and "Analysis of phase conjugation in a turbid medium."

I have also released my synthetic skin and random scattering models. I have created necessary support documentation so the models, written in MATLAB, are easy to understand. To increase their adoption, I have also released my FDTD code. This allows research groups to use the models without having to import them into another program.

 

After arriving at NTU, I presented my research as well as a quick lesson on the United States. I also participated in a high school competition where the competitors were asked to give presentations in English. I acted as the “American CEO” and, after the competition, provided insight in dealing with American companies and academics. During my last week in Taiwan, I gave another presentation. This time I focused on explaining what I learned in Taiwan and how their culture and habits appear to an American. At my fellow labmate's encouragement, I also discussed several potential partnership ideas for Taiwanese and American companies.

After returning to the United States, I gave a presentation in my lab group where I discussed by summer research and my experience in Taiwan. I also presented my experience in Taiwan to the Biomedical Engineering Club at Northeastern and will be giving a similar presentation to the college of engineering this December. Furthermore, I will travel to Brownsville, Texas and give a presentation at Hanna High School.

I worked with my professor, Charles DiMarzio, to develop a “dialogues of civilization” class at Northeastern University. We will take 12 NU undergrads to Taipei for a month this summer and teach about both cultures, as well as biomedical optics. This class will be taught in partnership with Professor Snow Tseng at NTU. This is the first time this has occurred and I am responsible for developing the cultural activities.
